awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Deciphering temporal events in mammalian cells using synthetic biology
awd_abstract_narration:
1553356
Wong, Wilson    

A fundamental goal in biology is to understand how cells make decisions when faced with external signal.  The proposed work will seek to understand how a cell, through genetic programs found in its genome, can distinguish signals that are varying in time (dynamics) and generate different outcomes.  A 'learning by building' approach will be used to engineer genetic systems that can decode dynamic signals.  Specifically, the PI will engineer novel genetic programs in living mammalian cells to enable it to interpret signal duration and sequence.  This approach will also provide a unique opportunity to bridge basic and applied science, where the novel genetic systems may be used in commercial applications.  A broader goal of this proposed work is to inspire students to design living cells, and train the next generation of workforce skilled in genetic engineering to address challenges in health, food, energy, and environment.  The education and outreach plans of this proposed work will accomplish these objectives by providing direct and stimulating research experience for undergraduates and underprivileged high school students, and developing classroom and laboratory based courses for students, high school teachers, and researchers.

This CAREER proposal aims to understand how genetic networks process information.  Such understanding will provide insight into a wide range of cellular processes.  The proposed work will seek to delineate the governing rules of genetic circuits that decipher dynamic signals and produce divergent output states with limited inputs.  In particular, two dynamical features, cumulative signal duration and temporal-order will be studied.  A forward engineering approach will be used to explore genetic circuits that can decode dynamics.  Specifically, the PI will (i) develop DNA recombinase-based cascade circuits to decode signal duration, and (ii) engineer and characterize two-input recombinase-based temporal-order sensing circuits.  A broader goal of this proposed work is to inspire students to design living cells, and train the next generation of workforce skilled in synthetic biology to address challenges in health, food, energy, and environment.  The education and outreach plans will accomplish these objectives by providing mentored laboratory-based research experience for undergraduates and underprivileged high school students, and by developing classroom and laboratory based courses for students, high school teachers, and researchers.
This CAREER award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
A fundamental goal in biology and my research program is to understand how cells process information and make decisions.  One of the most important tools that cells use is the genetic network, which is comprised of genes and DNA to form biological networks capable of performing computations akin to electronics.  Understanding how genetic networks can perform computation inside a cell will provide insights into a wide range of biological phenomena, such as how organ develops or how cancer arises.  The tools developed to study genetic circuits will also be very useful for engineering novel cell and gene therapies.

 

In this proposed work, we have made much notable progress.  In particular, we have developed a comprehensive platform for designing complex signal processing systems capable of robust logic computation paired with tight control over output expression levels in mammalian cells. There are two dominant paradigms for circuit design: transcription factor (TF)-based regulatory networks and computation via DNA recombination using site-specific recombinases (SSRs) or nucleases. Each of these systems fails to address key aspects of signal processing. The work we present here provides such a platform based on integrating site-specific recombinases and programmable transcription factors, called Computation via Recombinase Assisted Transcriptional Effectors (CREATE). CREATE establishes the first generalized design framework for coupling robust multi-input signal processing with the ability to generate digital, analog, or both types of output signals simultaneously. We present this platform as a universal architecture for programming complex signal processing devices in living cells. CREATE is engineered to be as broadly applicable as possible, which functions in a wide range of cell types and organisms and can be directed toward any number of engineered or endogenous genetic targets.

 

The second major achievement is that we have developed a large collection of toolset to control gene expression in mammalian cells.  Site-specific recombinases such as Cre and Flp are very powerful tools for regulating gene expression and have found many applications in engineering sophisticated genetic circuits and have been widely used in animal model development.  Chemical and light-inducible recombinases, in particular, are instrumental in providing spatial and temporal control of gene expression.  We now have the largest collection of inducible recombinases (>20 different systems), some of them have the best-in-class performance with a large signal to noise ratio.  We have also demonstrated the function of our inducible recombinases in mice.  We believe this collection of inducible recombinases will be extremely valuable to the animal genetic research and synthetic biology communities. 

 

We have also leveraged recombinase gene circuits in drug and genetic screens. Cell-based screenings have become indispensable for uncovering important protein targets and drug candidates that can regulate the phenotype of interest. A critical step of any screening experiment is quantifying the phenotypic changes after the genetic or chemical perturbations. Indeed, many methodologies and tools have been developed to measure cell states or quantify various pathway activities. In particular, one of the most widely used and important phenotypic readouts in cell-based screenings is pathway-specific transcription reporters due to their scalability, diversity, and adaptability to both chemical and genetic screens. While instrumental in many screening campaigns, transcription reporters are not without constraints and limitations. Transcription reporters can be plagued by weak activity with a low signal to noise ratio, which hinders our ability to identify essential yet nuanced targets.  Also, similar to other maker-based reporters, the transcription reporter's activity can be transient, which would require screening at multiple time points, a resource-intensive step.  Therefore, we developed a recombinase-based analog-to-digital reporter (RADAR) to drastically improve the capability and performance of transcription reporters in screens. Using our system, we uncovered several previously validated and unexpected regulators of the AP-1 signaling pathway, an important pathway in cancer and other diseases.

 

This proposal has generated insights into how complex genetic circuits can be readily programmed and a toolset to precisely reprogram mammalian cells.  Recognizing their potential impacts on the larger animal genetics research community all plasmids were and continue to be made available by depositing them to Addgene and Biobrick Foundation. 

 


Last Modified: 06/28/2022
Modified by: Wilson Wong
